qas.question: Where does the money made from wrestling come from?

answers.text: live event ticket sales, network television broadcasts, pay-per-view broadcasts, personal appearances by performers, branded merchandise and home video

qas.question: Where large places are some of the major wrestling shows held at?

answers.text: Madison Square Garden, as well as football stadiums

qas.question: What has the internet been utilized for in wrestling?

answers.text: to air web shows, internet pay-per-views (iPPVs) or on-demand content
WrestleMania, SummerSlam, Royal Rumble, and formerly Bash at the Beach, Halloween Havoc and Starrcade

qas.question: In which decade did wrestling start becoming very popular?

answers.text: Particularly since the 1950s, pro wrestling events have frequently been responsible for sellout crowds at large arenas

context: Although professional wrestling started out as petty acts in sideshows, traveling circuses and carnivals, today it is a billion-dollar industry. Revenue is drawn from <a0_0>live event ticket sales, network television broadcasts, pay-per-view broadcasts, personal appearances by performers, branded merchandise and home video<a0_0/>. <a4_0>Particularly since the 1950s, pro wrestling events have frequently been responsible for sellout crowds at large arenas<a4_0/>, including <a1_0>Madison Square Garden, as well as football stadiums<a1_0/>, by promotions including the WWE, the NWA territory system, WCW, and AWA. Pro wrestling was also instrumental in making pay-per-view a viable method of content delivery. Annual shows such as <a3_0>WrestleMania, SummerSlam, Royal Rumble, and formerly Bash at the Beach, Halloween Havoc and Starrcade<a3_0/> are among the highest-selling pay-per-view programming each year. In modern day, internet programming has been utilized by a number of companies <a2_0>to air web shows, internet pay-per-views (iPPVs) or on-demand content<a2_0/>, helping to generate internet-related revenue earnings from the evolving World Wide Web.
